Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Co-Creating a Research Agenda to Evaluate University Ambassador Programs' Impact on Engineering Identity of K-12 Students

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
A diverse workforce leads to more creative problem solving and is more socially just. Though great strides have been made to improve diversity, engineering remains predominantly white and male. Universities are attempting to increase diversity by conducting engineering outreach. Specifically, university students visit kindergarten through 12th grade classrooms and engage in discussions and activities intended to motivate student interest in engineering. However, what remains to be seen is if, and to what extent, these programs successfully increase the likelihood that students from traditionally underrepresented populations are pursuing engineering degrees and careers. This project seeks to bring together a diverse spectrum of stakeholders involved in engineering outreach such that a comprehensive, long-term research agenda can be developed. Through this agenda, researchers and program administrators will ultimately become better able to evaluate and assess whether programs effectively encourage diverse populations to pursue engineering careers, as well as help programs employ approaches that are more impactful.

The researchers seek to understand the long-term impact that ambassador programs have on engineering pathways and whether these programs help traditionally underserved students develop engineering identities. There is a need for intentional and longitudinal research to determine whether ambassador programs have real and lasting impact. Longitudinal studies are time and resource intensive and, the variation that exists across ambassador programs make small-scale studies only marginally useful. The engineering outreach community is often underfunded for the scale of social change it seeks to accomplish and conducting deep evaluation will allow for the better use of resources. Through research, the most effective strategies can be pinpointed and used to develop more effective outreach programming. Creating a unified research agenda that a diverse spectrum of stakeholders buy into, while challenging, has numerous benefits including: the development of an evaluation protocol that is used by programs across the county; the creation of relationships between K-12 and university personnel that results in longitudinal studies on engineering identity; and the development of models for scalable, effective program implementation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

The field of engineering has a longstanding problem with attracting and retaining people from diverse backgrounds, including people of color, women, low income populations, people with disabilities, and first-generation college students. University engineering ambassador programs were designed to contribute to outreach efforts intended to reach these underserved populations. They do so by having undergraduate engineering students enter k-12 classrooms in service of making engineering concepts, and in turn programs and careers, more accessible.

 

The purpose of the project at hand was to bring together diverse stakeholders in service of co-creating a research agenda for the ambassador-led outreach community. Stakeholders included: administrators, who supervised and created programs; k-12 teachers and administrators, who received the programs; researchers, who studied relevant topics; and non-profit organizations, who conducted similar outreach programming. A shared research agenda would allow these diverse stakeholders from across the country to gather data, implement change, and generally collaborate in a more cohesive, effective way.

 

The research agenda was created through a multi-step process which was designed to have the stakeholders? experiences and opinions shape the process by which the grant personnel gathered data, organized and facilitated meetings, and analyzed results; these components were foundational to building the research agenda.  The process included semi-structured interviews of 50 stakeholders and a two and a half day working group meeting with 36 stakeholders. Thematic analysis of the working meeting was used to draft the research agenda, which included six research streams. Stakeholders then participated in group deliberation and critique of the draft research agenda via video conference. The insights provided in the video conference was used to revise and finalize the research agenda.

 

The resulting research agenda and streams included a combination of theoretical research (strengthening engineering identity) and applied research (understanding how to communicate to stakeholder groups more effectively). The streams also included an internally focused initiative, outlining the development of a learning and sharing community for engineering ambassador program administrators. Research streams also contained more community-focused initiatives, that addressed questions like ?What do teachers want or need?,? ?How do we engage guidance counsellors?,? and ?How do we engage and support the families of k-12 students who are the recipients of outreach?? Ideally, these research streams will be executed by a consortium of stakeholders to ensure that implementation of each stream is useful across the diverse ambassador programs. The research agenda will function as a unified plan, allowing the engineering ambassador outreach community to move themselves forward on building knowledge so that ambassador-led outreach programs can be more impactful and better serve the communities that they strive to support.

 

In addition to the immediate benefits of a research agenda, there are other impacts of this project. First, eight students from three different universities received training and experience in qualitative research over the duration of this project. Seven undergraduate students received training and gained experience with ethnographic data collection in addition to their participation in the working group meeting. Two students (one of the undergraduate and a graduate student) acquired research experience in qualitative data analysis.

 

Second, the act of coming together as a community helped the participants build capacity through learning about each other?s programs, exchanging resources, and building their social networks. In addition to reporting participants reported exchanging contact information and organizing informal gatherings at conferences.

 

Third, this project employed a more radical co-creation approach which placed community feedback and input at the center of the entire process. Often structures are put in place during co-creation processes to increase expedience or lessen burden on stakeholders. In this project, community feedback was elicited in smaller details, including meeting agenda and registration creation as well as the facilitation of workshop sessions. Though the process of co-creation is challenging because it relies heavily on the engagement of community members, the benefits are more informed, robust outputs with more stakeholder buy in. As such, this may provide a useful foundation for other researchers and practitioners working at the convergence of engineering and outreach who may need to create a holistic map for their research community.

 

Finally, the implementation of the research agenda will lead to more effective and appropriate outreach efforts. This would include: programming that appeals to a broader array of people, ambassadors that are better equipped to mentor and support k-12 learners, and a more robust engineering ecosystem that reaches and supports children and their communities.
